unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Ghost Sightings: Investigating Proportions
question_text:
According to some studies, women are more likely to believe in ghosts than men. Casper wondered whether women were also more likely to report having seen a ghost than men and decided to do a study.
In Casper's random sample of $85$ women, $10$ women reported having seen a ghost at some point in their lives. In his random sample of $63$ men, only $4$ reported having seen a ghost.
Which of the following shows how to calculate the z-statistic for a test of the difference in the proportions of men and women who would report that they have seen a ghost?
solution:
To conduct a test for the difference in the proportions of men and women who would report that they have seen a ghost, we would use the following null hypothesis:

$${ H }_{ 0 }:{ p }_{ W }={ p }_{ M }$$

... where ${p}_{W}$ represents the proportion of women who would say they have seen a ghost and ${p}_{M}$ represents the proportion of men who would say they have seen a ghost.

We always start a significance test with the assumption that our null hypothesis is true. This would then imply that the following statement is also true:

$${ p }_{ W }-{ p }_{ M }=0$$

That is, we assume that the difference in the two proportions is $0$, and $0$ is our assumed value of the parameter.

To calculate a $z$-statistic we can use the following formula which is found in the reference materials provided with the AP Exam.

$$\text{standardized test statistic=} \dfrac{\text{statistic - parameter}}{\text{standard deviation of statistic}}$$

To find the value of the statistic, we simply subtract our observed proportions which we can write in fractional form:

$$\text{statistic}=\dfrac { 10 }{ 85 } -\dfrac { 4 }{ 63 }$$

We've already determined that the value of the parameter is $0$.

To determine the standard deviation of the statistic, we can once again just use the formula found in the reference materials provided with the A.P. Exam. Unfortunately, there are two formulas given for the standard deviation of the statistic when the statistic is a difference of sample proportions. Since our null hypothesis assumes ${ H }_{ 0 }:{ p }_{ W }={ p }_{ M }$, we should use the formula listed under the "special case when ${ p }_{ 1 }={ p }_{ 2 }$". This formula is:

$$\sqrt { p\left( 1-p \right) } \sqrt { \frac { 1 }{ { n }_{ 1 } } +\frac { 1 }{ { n }_{ 2 } } } $$

We can multiply these square roots together to express the standard deviation of the statistic in a different way:

$$\sqrt { p(1-p)\left( \frac { 1 }{ { n }_{ 1 } } +\frac { 1 }{ { n }_{ 2 } } \right) } $$

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect because it does not use the pooled proportion in the denominator of the formula.

Choice 'B' is incorrect. While the first two factors in the denominator do use the pooled proportion, the last factor in the denominator (which involves a sum) is not filled in correctly. Both fractions in this term should have a 1
in their numerator. They should not identify the number of successes in each sample.

Choice 'D' uses the other formula found in the reference materials provided with the AP Exam to determine the standard deviation of the statistic. This is not appropriate because we have assumed in our null hypothesis that the population proportions are equal.
